### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Cause an error in `Get-Culture` while using `-ErrorAction Stop` . It does not  terminate. 

### Expected behavior

console Terminating errors should cause the function to end. For example `Get-Item -Ea Stop`

```ps1
function funcShouldStop2 {
    # expects terminating error
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param()
    Get-Item 'somefakefilename' -ea Stop
    '⚠ Should Never Reach'
}
funcShouldStop2
```
No output

### Actual behavior

```ps1
function funcShouldStop1 {
    # expects terminating error
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param()
    Get-Culture 'en-uk' -ea Stop
    '⚠ Should Never Reach'
}
> funcShouldStop1

Get-Culture: 
Line |
   5 |      Get-Culture 'en-uk' -ea Stop
     |                  ~~~~~~~
     | Cannot validate argument on parameter 'Name'. The argument "en-uk" does not belong to the set ",aa,aa-DJ,aa-ER,aa-ET....snip....ns-MO,zh-SG,zh-Hant,zh-HK,zh-MO,zh-TW,zu,zu-ZA" specified by the ValidateSet attribute. Supply an argument that is in the set and then try the command again.
⚠ Should Never Reach
```

Note that it does reach `⚠ Should Never Reach`

comments.author: SeeminglyScience
comments.body: Parameter validation errors are pipeline terminating already so they do not change behavior with `ErrorActionPreference`

comments.author: ninmonkey
comments.body:
In that case, shouldn't this halt? 

```ps1
function funcShouldStop1 {
    # expects terminating error
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param()
    Get-Culture 'en-uk' -ea Stop
}
funcShouldStop1 -ea stop
'⚠ Should Never Reach'

# outputs: '⚠ Should Never Reach'
```

I thought it would, it doesn't. However wrapping it once more does halt.
```ps1
function funcShouldStop1 {
    # expects terminating error
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param()
    Get-Culture 'en-uk' -ea Stop
}
function funcShouldStopParent {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    param()
    funcShouldStop1 -ea stop 
}
funcShouldStopParent -ea stop
'⚠ Should Never Reach'

# output: 
```

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
> Parameter validation errors are pipeline terminating already so they do not change behavior with `ErrorActionPreference`

It's not always clear what's terminating and what isn't. Validation errors are before the command gets control of the error but ...
```function test1 {
del noththere
"here"
}

test1 
del : Cannot find path  ....

here
```
Just what we'd expect. 
```
 function test2 {
try {del noththere } catch {"there"}
"here"
}

test2
del : Cannot find path 

here
```
We can't _catch_ the error because it's not really _thrown._  That needs an `errorAction Stop` 
```
 function test3 {
try {del noththere -ea Stop } catch {"there"}
"here"
}

test3
there
here
```
Now we can catch it, and if we don't catch it the function stops. 
```
function test4 {
del noththere -ea Stop 
"here"
}

test4
del : Cannot find path

```
No surprises so far.  But let's put a validation error in ... 
```
function test5 {
del noththere -credential 1
"here"
}

test5
Remove-Item : Cannot process argument transformation  
here

```
So a validation error doesn't terminate just like the OP noticed.  But you _can_ catch it.
```
function test6 {
try {del noththere -credential 1} catch {"everywhere"} 
"here"
}

test6
everywhere
here
```
 EA Stop needs a bit of help to get the function to throw 
```
function test7 {
try {del noththere -credential 1} catch {throw $_} 
"here"
}

test7
Remove-Item : Cannot process argument transformation
```

I see cases where people use `try  {...}  catch {throw $_}`  where it's not needed, and I think is a habit created by this kind of thing

comments.author: SeeminglyScience
comments.body:
> In that case, shouldn't this halt?

Note the wording there, it's *pipeline* terminating, which works differently than *call stack* terminating errors.  `throw` and `-ea stop` are the latter, parameter validation and `PSCmdlet.ThrowTerminatingError` are the former.

Note I'm not defending this behavior, but it is by design.

comments.author: daxian-dbw
comments.body: WG-Engine reviewed this issue and we agreed with @SeeminglyScience's comment that the behavior is by design.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
> Get-Item 'somefakefilename' -ea Stop

For example in the OP this should be `Get-Item $null -ea Stop`  to demonstrate the same behavior as `Get-Culture 'en-uk' -ea Stop`
